abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact high. Salient lessons point at the
            structure of public-private partnerships (PPP) in India,
            where the transfer of construction and operating risks to
            the private sector, succeeded in creating a competitive,
            infrastructure capacity, achieved through comprehensive
            concession arrangements. To this end, inherent political,
            commercial, and financing risks were overcome through
            compensation in the event of nationalization, by assuring
            returns even at low traffic volumes, if needed through
            contract extension, and, guaranteeing to meet cost overruns,
            respectively. Most importantly, the proactive PPP approach
            was a defining factor in accelerating reforms, while risks
            proved to be important bottlenecks, much more so than the
            lack of appropriate financing, though further support should
            prod further reforms to improve operating conditions, and
            concession frameworks. Nonetheless, the acceptance of
            different risk allocations in India, still needs to be
            explored. As for the pace of subproject preparation, though
            initially envisaged to be a year period, in practice it took
            over five years each to reach financial close. Thus, while
            some shortening in the preparation cycle is still expected,
            complementing enhanced human capacity in the public sector
            could be the key, which would also include the bidding
            cycle. Also, weaknesses in the traffic and revenue
            projections needs to be revisited.
